Award.AwardTitle: Instrument-Cluster Studies of Equatorial Spread F
Award.AbstractNarration: The investigators will study the cause of the day-to-day variability in the development of plasma structure in the equatorial layer referred to as equatorial spread (ESF). The study will be based on the hypothesis that ESF originates from large-scale wave structure (LSWS). LSWS is an altitude modulation of isodensity contours in the bottomside layer that grows to large amplitudes. The modulation alters the background conditions that control development of ESF and features such as equatorial plasma bubbles (EPBs), a behavior that is of considerable interest to space weather. LSWS has been ignored almost completely by researchers for good reasons. Experimentalists have been unaware of its existence, and theorists have not considered it because its importance remained questionable. However, recent observations have shown that LSWS is real, occurs frequently in the evening equatorial layer, and appears to play a substantial role in the day-to-day variability of ESF and EPBs. The objectives of the study are twofold: (1) to extract as much information as possible about LSWS from well-designed experiments, data analysis, and theoretical studies, and (2) to investigate the day-to-day variability problem through a series of tasks that can test the working hypotheses. New paradigms will be constructed following those tests, and that cycle will be repeated throughout the course of the project. The studies will revolve around the analyses of unique databases and new experiments that will take advantage of a unique cluster of instruments, which is capable of extracting the properties of LSWS. The cluster is unique because it can distinguish spatial from temporal variations, and LSWS is essentially a stationary spatial structure during its growth phase. The goal of the project is to obtain a comprehensive description of LSWS, and derive considerable insight about seeding, LSWS amplification, and the development of EPBs. The results will also validate the crucial need for instrument clusters in studies of ESF.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Equatorial spread F (ESF) refers to a disturbed condition that develops in the equatorial region of the Earth's upper atmosphere (above 200 km altitude). When ESF occurs, the distribution of the electrically-charged particles (i.e., electrons and ions), referred to as the F-region ionospheric plasma, becomes highly irregular, which can cause the radio signals that propagate through this plasma to become severely distorted in amplitude and phase. A consequence is that distortions of this kind can seriously degrade the performance of communication and navigation systems that depend on the quality of these transionospherically-propagated radio signals. Given that mitigation of these deleterious effects does not appear to be a viable option, there is crucial need to develop a short-term (i.e., day-to-day) ESF forecasting capability.

            In terms of climatology, scientific results point clearly to the lifting of the F region (or layer) shortly after sunset (i.e., the so-called post-sunset rise, or PSSR) as the primary driver of the disturbance process. Daily monitoring of the vertical transport of the F layer has shown that this dependence does not have a one-to-one basis; instead, the scatter in ESF occurrence versus vertical transport is broad, which appears to point to the presence of another important driver (or process), but one that may become inconspicuously small when averaged over a climatological scale. In order to uncover the source of this day-to-day variability, field experiments were conducted as part of this project that involved clusters of instruments that were assembled to reduce the ambiguity between spatial and temporal variations. New measurements included (1) the reception of radio-beacon transmissions from the Air Force Communications/Navigation Outage Forecasting System (C/NOFS) satellite (with ground-based receivers) and (2) the mapping of the spatial distribution of small-scale irregularities in the ionospheric plasma with a ground-based phased-array radar. Other instruments in these clusters included ionosondes, all-sky imagers and Fabry-Perot interferometers (both operated at 630 nm), and GPS receivers.

            Substantial scientific progress has been made during the course of this project regarding the identity of the day-to-day ESF occurrence variability source. With information gleaned from the analyses of various data sources, the evidence that the source is an upwelling (i.e., a localized uplift in the bottomside of F layer) has continued to mount. A large percentage of observations indicate that ESF occurrence not only follows upwelling growth, but also that the ESF will appear within the confines of the upwelling region. Measurements have also shown that upwelling growth is produced by its own localized electric field. In other words, in addition to the large-scale electric field that produces the nightly PSSR, a localized electric field also appears; together, these seem to determine the conditions that lead to the development of ESF. Indications are that the day-to-day variability is associated with ambiguous measurements that may or may not include contributions from both electric fields. A significant portion of the scatter appears to arise from mixed measurements that include both those inside and outside of the upwellings.

            To better understand the physics of upwelling growth, a working hypothesis, referred to as the upwelling paradigm, has been constructed [Tsunoda, 2015]. This paradigm describes the stages through which a seed upwelling is initiated in the late afternoon and then amplified during the PSSR to produce a localized environment that is conducive to the development of equatorial plasma bubbles, the severest form of ESF. Analyses of data collected during experiments designed to test this working hypothesis have shown that while upwelling growth does seem to be related to the vigor of the PSSR when solar activity is high (as described by the upwelling paradigm), upwelling growth can be independent of the PSSR when solar activity is low. This breakthrough finding has uncovered a misconception that could compromise the accuracy of any short-term forecasting scheme that is based on the presumed underlying physics. This project has provided new insights based on instrument-cluster studies that are expected to lead to an eventual short-term forecasting strategy for ESF occurrence and evolution. These findings have been published in 12 scientific, peer-reviewed journal articles.
